title: I Was Hired To Watch Over a House at Night. It's Very Strange Here.
full_text:
The eviction notice might as well have been written in neon. Bold red letters screamed Final Notice across the top, and underneath in smaller, but equally damning print, the details of my failure laid out in bureaucratic precision. 30 days to vacate. Outstanding balance of $4,200. Legal action pending. I stood there in the hallway of my apartment building staring at the paper taped to my door like it was some kind of ancient curse. The adhesive had started to peel at one corner, probably from the humidity, and I found myself fixated on that small detail instead of the larger catastrophe it represented. $4,200. The number bounced around in my head, joining the chorus of other figures that had taken up permanent residence there over the past six months. Credit card debt, 11,000. Student loans, 38,000. Car payment, 347 monthly. Phone bill, 89. Groceries, whatever I could scrape together, which lately meant a lot of ramen and generic cereal. The mental calculator in my brain had become a torture device, constantly running tallies I couldn't escape. Six months ago, I'd been Sawyer Lee, marketing coordinator at Brennan & Associates, pulling down 52,000 a year and feeling pretty good about my trajectory. Not rich, but stable. Making my payments, building a little savings, even thinking about upgrading from my studio apartment to something with an actual bedroom. Then the company decided to restructure their marketing approach, which turned out to be corporate-speak for fire half the department and make the remaining people do twice the work. I'd gotten two weeks severance and a handshake from my boss, who couldn't quite meet my eyes when he delivered the news. Two weeks to find something new should've been manageable, right? I had experience, decent references, a college degree. The job market couldn't be that brutal. Turned out it could be exactly that brutal. The unemployment checks helped for a while, but they barely covered rent, let alone everything else. I'd burned through my savings by month three. Started putting groceries on credit cards by month four, and now here I was at month six staring at an eviction notice and trying to figure out which bills I could ignore for another week. My phone buzzed in my pocket. I didn't need to look at it to know what it was. Debt collectors had a particular rhythm to their calls. They'd try once in the morning, once around lunch, and once in the evening, like clockwork. This would be the lunch call from either Capital One or the collection agency handling my old medical bills from when I'd gotten food poisoning last year and had to go to the emergency room. The buzzing stopped, then started again almost immediately. Persistent today. I pulled the phone out and glanced at the screen. Unknown number with a local area code. Definitely a collector. They'd started using different numbers when I stopped answering the regular ones. I let it go to voicemail and fumbled for my keys. The lock on my door had been sticking lately, probably because the building was old enough to remember when Nixon was president. And I had to jiggle the key just right to get it to turn. The hallway smelled like someone had been cooking fish, mixed with the underlying mustiness that seemed to permeate every surface in this place. My apartment looked exactly like what it was, the living space of someone who'd given up on appearances about three months ago. Dishes in the sink that I'd been meaning to wash for two days. Laundry piled on the chair that was supposed to be for sitting, but had become a makeshift closet. The coffee table covered with bills, job applications, and the remains of whatever I'd managed to scrounge for breakfast. I dropped onto the couch and let the eviction notice fall onto the pile of other papers I'd been avoiding. 30 days. That was actually longer than I'd expected. The landlord, Mr. Kowalski, had been surprisingly patient considering I'd been two months behind since April. But patience had limits apparently, and I'd found mine. The smart thing would be to call him, try to work out some kind of payment plan. Maybe I could convince him to give me another month if I could come up with half the money upfront. But half of 4,000 was still 2,000, which might as well have been two million given my current account balance of $63 and change. I needed work. Not just any work, but something that paid immediately and paid well. The applications I'd been sending out for legitimate marketing jobs were disappearing into the void. Either I was overqualified, underqualified, or the position had been filled by someone's nephew. The retail and restaurant jobs I'd started applying for last month paid barely enough to cover gas money, and most of them wanted me to start at minimum wage despite my experience. My phone sat on the coffee table, silent now that the collector had given up. For a moment, I considered calling my parents, but that conversation would be worse than the eviction notice. They'd already bailed me out once when my car needed new brakes, and the disappointment in my mother's voice when I'd asked had been harder to take than the financial stress. They were retired, living on a fixed income, and shouldn't have to worry about their 32-year-old son who couldn't keep his life together. Jordan might have something. We'd stayed in touch since college and he always seemed to have his finger on various opportunities around town. Nothing permanent usually, but Jordan had a knack for finding short-term gigs that paid better than they should. He'd helped me pick up some freelance graphic design work a few months back, though that had dried up when the client decided to take their business to a cheaper overseas firm.I picked up my phone and scrolled through my contacts until I found his number. Jordan answered on the second ring, which was typical. He always answered his phone, no matter what time of day. "Sawyer. How's it going, man?" His voice had that perpetual cheerfulness that I'd never been able to figure out. Jordan had graduated with a degree in business administration, but had never seemed to hold down what anyone would call a traditional job, yet somehow he always had money, always had projects, always had connections. I'd stopped asking how it all worked years ago. "Been better," I said. "Actually, I was hoping you might know about any work opportunities, something that pays quickly." "Rough patch still ongoing?" "Getting rougher. Just got an eviction notice." There was a pause on the other end, and I could hear what sounded like traffic in the background. Jordan was probably driving somewhere, always heading to some meeting or appointment that he'd describe in vague terms if asked. "Damn, that's tough. How much time do they give you?" "30 days. But honestly, I need something now, like this week if possible." "Let me think." Another pause. "Actually, yeah, there might be something. It's a little unusual, but the pay is solid. You available to work nights?" "I'm available to work whenever. What kind of job?" "Security work. Private client needs someone to watch a property overnight. House-sitting basically, but they want someone there consistently, five nights a week, 8:00 PM to 8:00 AM." Security work wasn't something I'd considered, but it wasn't like I had room to be picky. "What's the pay?" "3,000 a week. Cash." I almost dropped the phone. $3,000 for five nights of work? That was more than I'd been making monthly at my old job. It had to be a mistake, or there had to be a catch that Jordan hadn't mentioned yet. "3,000? Are you sure?" "Positive. I know it sounds too good to be true, but the client values reliability and discretion. They've had problems with other security companies, people not following instructions, that kind of thing. They're willing to pay premium for someone who can follow simple directions." "What kind of instructions?" "Nothing complicated. Just sit in the house, make sure nothing gets disturbed. The place is empty right now. Going through some kind of transition period. They just need someone there to maintain a presence, you know? Make sure nobody breaks in, no vandalism, that sort of thing." It did sound too good to be true, but I was in no position to be skeptical about good fortune. 3,000 a week would not only cover my rent, but start making a real dent in my other debts. A month of that work and I could be back on solid ground. "What's the catch?" Jordan laughed. "You're always looking for the downside, Sawyer. Sometimes a good opportunity is just a good opportunity. But since you asked, there are some specific requirements. No lights on in the house while you're there. No electronics, no phone calls, no music, nothing like that. And once you're there for the night, you don't leave until morning. No exceptions." The requirements were odd, but not unreasonable. Plenty of security jobs had strange protocols. Maybe the client was worried about drawing attention to an empty house, or there were insurance requirements about maintaining a low profile. "Where's the house?" "Maple Street, over in the Riverside neighborhood. Quiet area, nice houses. You'd start Monday if you're interested." Riverside was a decent part of town. Older homes, but well-maintained. Not the kind of place where I'd expect trouble, which made the job sound even more appealing, sitting in a quiet house for 12 hours, five nights a week, for $3,000. I'd brought books, catch up on some reading I'd been meaning to do. "And this is legitimate? Not some kind of insurance scam or anything?" "Come on, man. You know I wouldn't put you in a bad situation. This is a private client who values their privacy and is willing to pay for peace of mind. Nothing shady about it." My phone buzzed with another incoming call. Another unknown number, another debt collector who wanted to discuss my payment options. I let it go to voicemail and focused on Jordan's offer. "When would I get paid?" "Weekly, every Friday. Cash, like I said. You work Monday through Friday, get paid Friday afternoon." $3,000 in cash by the end of next week. It would solve my immediate crisis and give me breathing room to figure out something more permanent. The strange requirements didn't matter. I could sit in a dark house for 12 hours if it meant keeping my apartment and getting my life back on track. "I'll take it." "Great. I'll let them know you're interested. Can you start this Monday?" "Absolutely." "Perfect. I'll get you the address and details over the weekend. And Sawyer, this could be a really good thing for you. Just follow the rules exactly as they're explained and everything will work out fine." Something in his tone made me want to ask more questions, but the eviction notice was still sitting on my coffee table, and my bank account was still hovering near zero. Whatever minor weirdness came with this job, I could handle it for $3,000 a week. "Thanks, Jordan. I really appreciate this." "No problem. That's what friends are for, right?" After we hung up, I sat on my couch and tried to process what had just happened. An hour ago, I'd been staring at financial ruin-Now, I had a job that would pay more in a week than most people made in a month. It seemed impossible, but Jordan had never steered me wrong before. The weekend stretched ahead of me, and for the first time in months, I had something to look forward to instead of dread. Monday night, I'd be sitting in a house on Maple Street, earning money just by being present. No customers to deal with, no boss breathing down my neck, no performance reviews or office politics. Just me, an empty house, and enough money to get my life back on track. What could possibly go wrong with an arrangement that simple? The weekend crawled by with the kind of restless energy that made sitting still impossible. I kept checking my phone, waiting for Jordan to text me the address and details. Every time it buzzed, my stomach jumped. But it was always another debt collector or some automated reminder about a bill I couldn't pay anyway. By Sunday evening, I'd cleaned my entire apartment twice and reorganized my meager closet three times just to keep my hands busy. Jordan finally called Sunday night around 9:00. "You ready for tomorrow?" His voice carried that same confident tone from Friday, but underneath it, I caught something else. Urgency maybe, or impatience. "Been ready since we talked," I said. "Just need to know where I'm going." "1247 Maple Street. It's in Riverside, about 15 minutes from your place. Nice neighborhood, quiet. I'll meet you there at 7:30 to show you around and hand over the key." I grabbed a pen and scribbled the address on the back of an envelope. "Anything else I should know?" "Just remember what I told you. No lights, no leaving, no noise. The client is very particular about these things." His tone sharpened. "I mean it, Sawyer. Follow the rules exactly." The way he said it made my skin prickle. Jordan had always been laid-back about everything, the kind of guy who showed up 20 minutes late to dinner and shrugged it off with a joke. This intensity was new. "Got it," I said. "No lights, no leaving, no noise." "Good. See you tomorrow." The line went dead before I could ask any follow-up questions. Monday dragged worse than the weekend. I spent most of the day trying to distract myself with job applications, but my mind kept wandering to the house on Maple Street. $3,000 for sitting in a dark house five nights a week, it still seemed too good to be true, but I'd stopped questioning good luck. I needed this job too badly to overthink it. By 7:15, I was already driving through Riverside, taking my time to get familiar with the area. Jordan was right about it being quiet. Tree-lined streets, well-maintained sidewalks, houses with actual yards instead of the cramped apartment complexes I was used to. The kind of neighborhood where people probably knew their neighbors' names and complained about kids riding bikes too fast. 1247 Maple Street sat in the middle of a block of similar two-story houses. Nothing fancy, but solid and respectable. White siding, black shutters, a small front porch with two steps leading up to the door. A narrow driveway ran along the left side, but there was no car parked there. The windows were dark, and the whole place had that empty feeling houses get when nobody's lived in them for a while. Jordan's beat-up Honda was already parked at the curb. He got out when he saw me pull up, wearing dark jeans and a black jacket that made him blend into the evening shadows. Even his usual easy smile looked forced. "Right on time," he said as I approached the front porch. "I like that." "Seemed like punctuality was important to you," I said, trying to keep my tone light. He pulled a single brass key from his pocket and held it up. "This is yours for the next five nights. Don't lose it, because I won't be able to get you another one until Friday." The key was warm from his hand when he dropped it into my palm. Standard house key, nothing special about it except the weight of what it represented. $3,000 a week. Enough to catch up on rent, pay down some debt, maybe even buy groceries that didn't come in a foam cup. Jordan unlocked the front door and pushed it open. The hinges creaked softly and cool air drifted out, carrying the smell of dust and something else I couldn't identify. Not unpleasant, just stale, like a room that hadn't been opened in months. "Come on, I'll show you around," he said, stepping inside. I followed him into a small entryway that opened directly into the living room. My eyes needed a moment to adjust to the dimness, but gradually I could make out the basic layout. Hardwood floors, a few pieces of furniture covered with sheets, windows with heavy curtains drawn tight. To the right, a doorway led to what looked like a kitchen. Straight ahead, a staircase climbed to the second floor. "This is where you'll spend most of your time," Jordan said, gesturing around the living room. "There's a chair under that sheet that's comfortable enough. Kitchen's through there if you need water, but don't use the lights. There's a bathroom down the hall past the kitchen." I pulled the sheet off the chair he'd indicated. It was an old recliner, brown leather worn soft at the arms and headrest. The kind of chair someone's grandfather might have fallen asleep in while watching the evening news. "What about upstairs?" I asked. Jordan's expression tightened. "Off limits. You don't go upstairs, period. That's one of the most important rules." "Why? What's up there?""Nothing that concerns you?" His voice had gone flat, all the friendliness drained out of it. "Look, Sawyer, I'm serious about this. The client has very specific requirements. You sit in this chair, you keep the lights off, you don't leave until 8:00 in the morning, no matter what you hear or see. That's the job." The phrase, "No matter what you hear or see," stuck in my mind like a splinter. "What am I going to hear or see?" "Probably nothing. Old houses make noise, that's all. Settling, pipes, maybe some mice in the walls. The point is, you ignore it and stay put." He checked his watch. "I need to go. You've got everything you need?" I looked around the dim room again. Chair, access to water and a bathroom, strict instructions to sit still and do nothing for 12 hours. It should've been the easiest job in the world. "Yeah, I think so." "Good." Jordan headed for the door, then paused with his hand on the knob. "Remember, Sawyer, no lights, no leaving, no going upstairs. Follow those rules and you'll get paid Friday afternoon. Break them," he shrugged, "Well, don't break them." The door closed behind him with a soft click, and I heard his car start up outside. Within a minute, the sound of his engine faded down the street, leaving me alone in the silent house. I settled into the leather recliner and tried to get comfortable. The seat had molded itself to someone else's body over the years, but it wasn't unpleasant, just different. I pulled out my phone to check the time, 7:45, 12 hours and 15 minutes to go. The darkness wasn't complete. Thin lines of light leaked around the edges of the curtains from the street lights outside, just enough to make out the basic shapes of the room. The covered furniture looked like sleeping animals in the dim glow. I found myself wondering who had lived here before, why they'd left, and why someone was paying me $3,000 a week to sit in their empty house. But those were questions for another time. Tonight, I was getting paid to sit still and keep quiet. After months of unemployment and mounting debt, it was exactly the kind of boring, mindless work I needed. The first hour passed quietly. I heard cars driving by occasionally, the distant sound of a dog barking, someone's television through an open window down the street. Normal neighborhood sounds that gradually faded as people settled in for the night. My eyes had fully adjusted to the darkness now, and I could make out more details of the room. A fireplace against the far wall, bookshelves on either side of it, a coffee table in front of my chair with magazines scattered across its surface. I tried not to think about how much money I was earning just by sitting here. $62.50 an hour, if I'd done the math right. More than I'd ever made in my life, and all I had to do was exist in this chair until morning. Around 10:30, I heard footsteps on the sidewalk outside. They slowed as they passed the house, and I held my breath, wondering if someone was going to knock on the door. But the footsteps continued on, and a minute later, I heard a door close somewhere down the block. By 11:00, the neighborhood had gone completely quiet. No more cars, no more voices, no more television sounds. Just the kind of deep silence that only comes late at night in residential areas. I'd grown up in apartments where you could always hear something through the walls, so the complete quiet felt strange. Not uncomfortable exactly, but noticeable. That's when I first heard the tapping. It was faint, rhythmic, coming from somewhere above my head. Tap, tap, tap. Pause. Tap, tap, tap. Pause. Like someone drumming their fingers on a table or maybe a tree branch hitting a window in the breeze. I looked up at the ceiling, trying to pinpoint where the sound was coming from, but it seemed to move around. Jordan had warned me about house noises. Old buildings settled, pipes expanded and contracted, small animals got into the walls. This was probably just what he'd been talking about. Nothing to worry about. The tapping continued for maybe five minutes, then stopped. I relaxed back into the chair and checked my phone again. 11:15. Still over eight hours to go, but I was getting paid well enough to be patient. The quiet stretched on. I found myself listening more carefully now, aware of every small sound. The house creaking as it cooled down from the day's heat. A car starting up several blocks away. The hum of the refrigerator in the kitchen, cycling on and off. Around midnight, the tapping started again. This time, it was louder, more insistent. Still rhythmic, but faster now. Tap, tap, tap, tap. Pause. Tap, tap, tap, tap. Pause. Definitely coming from upstairs, though it seemed to move from room to room. I found myself tracking it across the ceiling, following the sound as it went from what I guessed was the front bedroom to the back of the house, and then back again. I reminded myself of Jordan's instructions. Ignore whatever I heard, stay in the chair, don't go upstairs under any circumstances. This was just an old house doing what old houses do. But the tapping was getting harder to ignore. It had a deliberate quality that didn't match my mental image of settling wood or expanding pipes. Too regular. Too purposeful. Like someone was trying to get my attention,After about 10 minutes, the tapping stopped again. The silence that followed felt heavier somehow, loaded with expectation. I strained my ears waiting for it to start up again, but the house had gone quiet. I checked my phone, 12:20. The night was still young and I was already feeling jumpy. This was going to be a long 12 hours if I couldn't get my nerves under control. 20 minutes later, I heard something that made my stomach clench. It wasn't tapping this time. It was a muffled banging sound, like someone hitting a wall with their fist. Three solid thumps, pause, three more thumps, pause. The sound was definitely coming from upstairs, and it was loud enough that I felt it in my chest. I gripped the arms of the chair and forced myself to stay seated. Jordan had been very clear about the rules. No matter what I heard, I was supposed to ignore it and stay put. He'd emphasized that point multiple times, which suggested he'd known I might hear things that would make me want to investigate. The banging continued for several minutes, moving around the upstairs like the tapping had. Sometimes it sounded like it was coming from directly overhead, sometimes from the front or back of the house. Always the same pattern. Three hits, pause, three hits, pause. I tried to convince myself it was pipes, water hammer maybe, or the heating system cycling on and off. But it was January and the house felt cold enough that I doubted anyone was running the heat, and the rhythm was too consistent, too purposeful. The sound stopped abruptly, leaving me sitting in the sudden quiet with my heart racing and my hands clenched on the chair arms. I realized I'd been holding my breath and forced myself to exhale slowly. Whatever was happening upstairs, it wasn't my problem. I was being paid to sit in this chair and mind my own business. $3,000 was worth dealing with some mysterious house noises, even if they were making my skin crawl. But as the silence stretched on, broken only by the distant hum of the refrigerator, I couldn't shake the feeling that something was very wrong with this job. I couldn't sit in that chair anymore. My muscles ached from staying rigid for the past hour, and the silence felt worse than the banging had. At least when the sounds were happening, I knew where they were coming from. Now I had no idea if whatever was making them had stopped or just moved somewhere I couldn't hear. The floorboards creaked under my feet as I stood up. The sound seemed impossibly loud in the quiet house, and I froze for a moment listening. Nothing responded to the noise. No footsteps above, no tapping, no banging. Just the steady hum of the refrigerator from the kitchen and the occasional car passing outside. I needed to know what was happening up there. Jordan had said not to go upstairs, but he hadn't explained why. Maybe there was a simple explanation for all this. Maybe someone was supposed to be in the house and Jordan had forgotten to mention it. Or maybe there really was some kind of animal in the walls or attic. Either way, sitting downstairs and letting my imagination run wild wasn't helping anything. Moving toward the stairs felt like walking through thick water. Every step required conscious effort, and my hand shook slightly as I reached for the banister. The wood was smooth and cool under my palm, worn down by years of people climbing these same steps. I wondered if any of them had heard the same sounds I was hearing now. The first step groaned under my weight. I paused, listening again, but the house remained silent. The second step was quieter, and by the third, I'd found a rhythm that minimized the noise. My eyes had adjusted to the darkness enough that I could make out the shape of the hallway at the top of the stairs, though the details remained hidden in shadow. Halfway up, I stopped. The sounds had been coming from directly above the living room, which would put them somewhere near the front of the house. But as I climbed higher, I realized the tapping and banging had seemed to move around. First from one direction, then another, like someone walking from room to room, testing the walls or floors. The top of the stairs opened onto a narrow hallway that ran the length of the house. Three doorways branched off to my right and one to my left. All of them stood open, revealing nothing but darkness beyond. The air up here felt different than downstairs. Cooler maybe, and with a staleness that suggested these rooms hadn't been used in a while. I stood perfectly still and listened. My own breathing sounded too loud, so I held my breath for 30 seconds, straining to hear anything else. Nothing. No movement, no settling, no mysterious tapping. Whatever had been making noise down there had gone completely quiet the moment I'd started climbing the stairs. The first room on my right appeared to be a bedroom. I could make out the bulk of a bed frame and dresser, both covered with the same kind of sheets that had been draped over the living room furniture. Dust motes danced in the faint light coming through a gap in the curtains. I stepped inside and looked around carefully, checking the corners and behind the furniture. Everything sat exactly where it should. No signs of disturbance, no evidence that anyone or anything had been moving around in here. The second room was smaller, maybe an office or spare bedroom. A desk sat against one wall with a chair tucked neatly underneath.Papers were scattered across the surface, but when I got closer, I could see they were just old bills and letters, yellowed with age. The third room was another bedroom, this one with two windows facing the street. I pulled one of the curtains aside slightly and looked down at my car parked in the driveway. From up here, I could see most of the neighborhood. Porch lights glowed at regular intervals down the block, and a few windows showed the blue flicker of late night television. Everything looked normal and peaceful. The bathroom was across the hall. Old fixtures, clean, but clearly unused for some time. The medicine cabinet was empty except for a bottle of aspirin that had expired three years ago. The bathtub was bone-dry, and a thin layer of dust covered the sink. I'd been upstairs for maybe 20 minutes and I hadn't found anything that could explain the sounds. No loose floorboards, no signs of animals, no hidden speakers or mechanical devices. The rooms felt abandoned, but not disturbed. Whatever had been making all that noise had either vanished completely or was somewhere I hadn't looked yet. Standing in the hallway again, I tried to retrace the path the sounds had taken. The tapping had started above the living room, which would be the front bedroom. Then it had moved toward the back of the house, maybe to the office. The banging had seemed to come from multiple locations, like someone moving from room to room and hitting the walls, but I just checked every room and none of them showed any signs of recent activity. The silence was starting to feel oppressive. I'd gotten used to the constant background noise of the sounds upstairs, and now their absence felt almost worse than their presence. At least when I could hear something, I knew where to focus my attention. Now, I felt like I was waiting for something to jump out at me from any direction. I made my way back downstairs, testing each step carefully to minimize the creaking. The living room felt different when I returned to it. Smaller maybe, or more confined. The chair I'd been sitting in looked lonely in the middle of all that empty space, and I realized I didn't wanna sit back down. The idea of spending the next six hours trapped in that recliner listening for sounds that might or might not come made my stomach clench. But I didn't have much choice. Jordan was paying me $3,000 to sit in this house and follow his rules. I hadn't technically broken any of them by going upstairs. He'd said not to go up there, but he hadn't been specific about consequences or enforcement, and I'd needed to investigate the sounds for my own peace of mind. Now that I'd confirmed there was nothing obviously wrong up there, I could probably get through the rest of the night without losing my mind. The hours crawled by. I dozed fitfully in the chair, jerking awake every time the house made a normal settling noise. Around 4:00 in the morning, I heard a car door slam somewhere down the block, followed by footsteps on pavement and the sound of keys jingling. Someone coming home late from work or a night out. Normal neighborhood sounds that reminded me there was a whole world of regular people doing regular things just outside these walls. Dawn came slowly. Gray light gradually replacing the orange glow of the streetlights. I could hear birds starting to sing and the distant hum of early morning traffic. The house felt different in daylight. Less threatening somehow. The furniture shapes that had seemed ominous in the darkness now looked like what they were, old chairs and tables covered with dust sheets. By 7:30, I was watching the street through a gap in the curtains, waiting for Jordan's car to appear. My body ached from spending 12 hours in the recliner and my eyes felt gritty with exhaustion. I'd managed to get through the night, but I wasn't sure how many more nights like this one I could handle. Jordan's Honda pulled into the driveway at exactly 8:00. I watched him get out and walk to the front door, moving with the same casual confidence he'd shown the night before. When he knocked, I unlocked the door and stepped aside to let him in. "How'd it go?" He asked, looking around the living room as if checking to make sure everything was still in place. "Fine," I said, then hesitated. "Mostly fine. There were some noises during the night." Jordan's expression didn't change. He continued looking around the room, his gaze settling on the recliner and the coffee table. "What kind of noises?" "Tapping and banging from upstairs. It went on for a few hours, then stopped." "Old houses make sounds," Jordan said, his tone dismissive. "Pipes expanding and contracting, wood settling, that kinda thing. You get used to it." "This sounded more deliberate than that. Like someone walking around up there." Jordan finally looked at me directly. His gray eyes were flat and unreadable. "There's nobody upstairs, Sawyer. The house is empty except for you. Just focus on following the rules and everything will be fine." I wanted to push the issue, to tell him about going upstairs and finding nothing, but something in his tone warned me off. This wasn't a conversation he wanted to have and I needed this job too much to risk annoying him over something I couldn't explain anyway. "Okay," I said. "I can handle it." "Good. Same time tonight. I'll see you at 8:00." Jordan left without another word, and I locked the door behind him before walking to my car. The morning air felt cool and clean after spending 12 hours in the stale atmosphere of the house. I sat in the driver's seat for a moment before starting the engine, looking back at the white house with its black shutters and drawn curtains. In daylight, it looked completely ordinary, just another house in a quiet neighborhood.... but I knew I'd be back tonight, and I wasn't looking forward to it. The second night started the same way. Jordan arrived at 7:30 with the key and the same brief instructions. No lights, no leaving, no noise. He didn't ask about the previous night, and I didn't volunteer any information. The handover took less than five minutes, and then I was alone again in the dark living room with 12 hours stretching ahead of me. I'd spent the day trying to research the house online, but the address didn't turn up anything unusual. Property records showed it had been owned by the same family for 30 years before being sold six months ago to a company I'd never heard of. No reports of break-ins or disturbances, no local news stories or neighborhood complaints. As far as the internet was concerned, 1247 Maple Street was completely unremarkable. The sounds started earlier this time. I'd been in the chair for maybe two hours when the first tapping began. Same rhythm as before, but louder and more insistent. Tap-tap-tap-pause. Tap-tap-tap-pause. It came from directly overhead, moving slowly from the front of the house toward the back. Then it stopped and the banging started. This time, it was definitely louder than the night before. The sound reverberated through the house like someone hitting the walls with a hammer. Three sharp bangs, pause, three more bangs, pause. The pattern continued for 10 minutes, moving from room to room upstairs. But tonight, I could hear something else mixed in with the banging. Footsteps. Clear, deliberate footsteps pacing back and forth across the floor above me. Not the quick scurrying of an animal or the random settling of old wood. These were the footsteps of someone walking with purpose, someone who knew exactly where they were going. I gripped the arms of the recliner and forced myself to stay seated. Jordan had been clear about the rules, and I'd already pushed the boundaries once by going upstairs. But the sounds were so much more obvious tonight that ignoring them felt impossible. Whoever or whatever was up there wasn't even trying to be subtle anymore. The pacing continued for another hour, sometimes fast and agitated, sometimes slow and methodical.
